Award.AwardTitle: TWC SBE: Option: Frontier: Collaborative: Towards Effective Web Privacy Notice and Choice: A Multi-Disciplinary Prospective

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural language privacy policies have become a de facto standard to address expectations of notice and choice on the Web. Yet, there is ample evidence that users generally do not read these policies and that those who occasionally do struggle to understand what they read. Initiatives aimed at addressing this problem through the development of machine implementable standards or other solutions that require website operators to adhere to more stringent requirements have run into obstacles, with many website operators showing reluctance to commit to anything more than what they currently do. This project offers the prospect of overcoming the limitations of current natural language privacy policies without imposing new requirements on website operators.

This frontier project builds on recent advances in natural language processing, privacy preference modeling, crowdsourcing, formal methods, and privacy interfaces to overcome this situation. It combines fundamental research with the development of scalable technologies to semi-automatically extract key privacy policy features from natural language website privacy policies and present these features to users in an easy-to-digest format that enables them to make more informed privacy decisions as they interact with different websites. Work in this project also involves the systematic collection and analysis of website privacy policies, looking for trends and deficiencies both in the wording and content of these policies across different sectors and using this analysis to inform ongoing public policy debates. An important part of this project is to work closely with stake holders in industry to enable the transfer of these technologies to industry for large-scale deployment.

Performance_Institution.Name: Center for Internet & Society, Stanford Law School

POR.DRECONTENT:
Background:

The Usable Privacy Policy Project has developed technologies to semi-automatically analyze the text of privacy policies. As part of this subcontract with Stanford University, the teams at Carnegie Mellon University and Fordham University have extended this work to analyze mobile apps for privacy compliance issues. Last year, this included contributions to the development, evaluation and refinement of a mobile app privacy compliance tool and a first study of 18,000 mobile apps[1]. The tool combines the extraction of statements from the text of privacy policies with the analysis of the code of mobile apps to identify potential privacy compliance issues. Last year, the tool had been piloted with members of the California Office of the Attorney General..

 

Accomplishments Over the Past Year

Over this final year of the subcontract, the mobile app compliance tool underwent major improvements. This included the development of new, more accurate classifiers to extract statements from the text of privacy policies as well as new and improved static code analysis techniques. These improvements were motivated by further evaluation of the previous version of the tool, including a collaboration with the Office of the New York State Attorney General during the summer of 2017. The improvements focused on supporting a more flexible analysis framework, where analysis results can be filtered to zoom in on specific types of compliance issues and various features of mobile apps (e.g. categories of mobile apps such as apps targeted to children, number of downloads, etc.). They also included the development of finer grain classifiers to zoom in on more specific types of disclosures (e.g. classifiers focusing on the disclosure of different types of location tracking technologies, different types of unique identifiers, etc.) For instance, these classifiers enable the tool to more specifically differentiate between privacy policy statements pertaining to the use of fine grain location tracking technologies such as GPS, WiFi, or beacons and more generic disclosures about the collection of location data.  The finer grain classifiers are supplemented with coarser grain classifiers that look for more generic disclosures (or lack thereof) such as more generic disclosures about the collection of location data. The resulting tool was used to help the Center for Democracy and Technology compile mobile app privacy compliance results as part of a report on connected cars [2]. In Fall 2017, we also significantly scaled the infrastructure required to analyze large numbers of apps. In Spring 2018, the tool was used to analyze over 1 million free Android apps downloaded from the Google Play store.

 

Results from this research were presented at PLSC (June 2017), SOUPS (July 2017), the workshop on “Privacy Engineering Research and the GDPR” (Nov, 2017), the FTC Privacy Con (Feb . 2018), and the Annual Privacy Forum (June 2018). Our research has also continued to be featured in the media and was also featured on NSF’s “News From the Field Website” [6]. See [7] for a more comprehensive list of presentations and media coverage.

[3] Peter Story, Sebastian Zimmeck, Norman Sadeh, "Which Apps have Privacy Policies?", Carnegie Mellon University Technical Report CMU-ISR-18-100, Institute for Software Research, School of Computer Science, Feb 2018 [pdf]
